questions.text:
About incentives in NTEP, which of the following statements are true?
  1. 500 rupees monthly(treatment months) for nutritional supplementation.
  2. Food baskets are provided yearly to TB patients.
  3. 500 rupees is provided for every case notification.
  4. 2500 rupees is given after successful treatment of MDR-TB to the treatment provider.
questions.solution:
True statements about NTEP incentives are:

1. 500 rupees are monthly for nutritional supplementation.

3. 500 rupees are provided for every case notification.

NTEP(National Tuberculosis Elimination Program) is run by the Government of India to combat and reduce the disease burden caused by Tuberculosis in India. It is based on four strategic pillars of "Detect - Treat - Prevent - Build". Under the umbrella of NTEP, various schemes provide incentives and financial benefits to patients as well as health workers.

Under Nikshay Poshan Yojana, a financial incentive of Rs.500/- per month is provided for nutritional support to each notified TB patient for the duration for which the patient is on anti-TB treatment.

Under the TB Mukt Bharat Abhiyan, monthly food baskets are provided to patients suffering from TB. These methods are aimed to reduce the out-of-pocket expenditure of patients with TB.

Also under Nikshay, Rupees 500 are provided to health workers and private practitioners for notifying about a confirmed TB case. The guideline for TB notification under the NTEP is within 30 days (a month) of receiving a new case. The notification must be done to the District Health Officer or the Chief Medical Officer of a District Hospital by the practitioner who diagnosed it.

Also under the Direct Transfer Benefit scheme of Nikshay on successful completion of treatment, treatment providers are given 2000 rupees for treating drug-sensitive, and 5000 rupees for treating drug-resistant TB.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the WHO Next Generation Partograph?
  1. The plotting begins from the latent phase of labour
  2. The active phase begins from 5cm of cervical dilatation
  3. Alert line and action line are present for guidance
  4. The second stage of labour is also plotted
  5. It is to be used in all levels of healthcare facilities
questions.solution:
True statements about the WHO Next Generation Partograph/WHO Labour Care Guide are:

2.)The active phase begins from 5cm of cervical dilatation

4.)The second stage of labour is also plotted

5.)It is to be used in all levels of healthcare

WHO Labour Care Guide is the labour monitoring tool that includes new recommendations from the WHO based on emerging evidence on normal labour progression. The new WHO Next Generation Partograph(2020) differs from the previous WHO-modified partograph(2000) in the following aspects:

a.)Documentation of labour progression starts only in the active stage and begins from 5 cm of cervical dilatation.

b.)No action and alert lines. Rather it has time-based cut-offs for each centimetre of cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician to take action.

c.)Monitoring of the second stage of labour is included.

d.)Addition of a section on supportive care of the mother- labour companionship, pain relief, oral fluid intake and posture.

e.)Strength of Uterine contraction is not recorded, only frequency and duration of the contraction are noted.

The WHO labour care guide is to be implemented in all levels of health care(primary, secondary and tertiary) and is to be implemented globally(but especially in resource-limited countries). It includes assessments and observations that are essential for the care of all pregnant women, regardless of their risk status.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: All of the following are indications of Retrograde intrarenal surgery to remove renal stones except?
questions.solution:
Lower pole calculi and not of the Upper pole is an indication to perform RIRS(Retrograde intrarenal surgery).

RIRS is an endoscopic approach for managing renal stones. A slimmer and more flexible URS(Ureterorenoscopes) with an active defection of the tip and laser technology is used to perform RIRS. The scope has thinner fibres which allow for retrograde access to the kidney via the ureteric orifice. Thus it provides as an

Indications for Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) are:

  •  Renal stones <2 cm.
  • Lower pole calculi.
  • Obesity
  • Musculoskeletal deformities (e.g. kyphoscoliosis) and renal anomalies (horseshoe kidney or pelvic kidney).
  • Bleeding diathesis. 

RIRS avoids the morbidity associated with percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). Laser is used as an energy source for stone fragmentation. URS and RIRS can also be used in patients with bleeding disorders, as they are less invasive than PCNL. Complications include ureteric perforation and avulsion although they occur less frequently with highly flexible scopes.

 

 

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

questions.text:
Which of the following parameters are included in the Eckardt score for achalasia?
  1. Weight Loss
  2. Dysphagia
  3. Abdominal pain
  4. Regurgitation
questions.solution:
The Achalasia-Eckardt score includes 4 parameters. They are weight loss, dysphagia, Retrosternal pain and Regurgitation. Abdominal pain is not a part of the scoring.

Achalasia is a primary oesophagal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of oesophagal peristalsis and impaired lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. 

It presents with a characteristic triad of Dysphagia, Regurgitation and Weight loss. On the barium swallow, the bird's beak appearance of the oesophagus is seen in Achalasia. Esophageal manometry is the "gold standard" investigation for diagnosis. The manometry findings seen in Achalasia are impaired LES relaxation and absent peristalsis with elevated LES pressure. Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer.

The ‘Eckardt score’ has been developed to assess the severity of symptoms and monitor outcomes in patients with Achalasia.

Score Weight loss(in kgs) Dysphagia  Retrosternal pain Regurgitation
0 None None None None
1 <5 Occasionally Occasionally Occasionally
2 5-10 Daily Daily Daily
3 >10 Each meal Each meal  Each meal

A higher score translates to severe disease.

Achalasia management can be medical, including sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates or calcium channel blockers. But medical management has a limited role in the treatment and surgical intervention is sooner or later needed. Laparoscopic myotomy, pneumatic balloon dilatation and POEM(Peroral endoscopic myotomy) are effective treatments for achalasia.

 

The image below shows the Bird's beak appearance of the oesophagus on the barium swallow.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the modified Duke criteria for a definitive diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis
The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established
Presence of 1 major + 2 minor is definitive endocarditis in clinical criteria

questions.solution:
If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major (or) 1 major + 3 minor (or) 5 minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding TB drug resistance?
  1. RR TB should be proven to be sensitive to Isoniazid. 
  2. MDR-TB implies resistance to Isoniazid and Rifampicin
  3. Pre-XDR-TB is MDR-TB plus resistance to at least one group A drug(Bedaquilline or Linezolid)
  4. XDR-TB is resistant to all current medications available for the treatment of TB.
questions.solution:
True statements is MDR-TB implies resistance to Isoniazid and Rifampicin.

The NTEP classifies drug resistance patterns for TB into 5 groups:

Rifampicin Resistance (RR) Unknown/ Sensitive Resistant Unknown/ Sensitive Unknown/ Sensitive
Multi Drug Resistance TB (MDR TB Resistant Resistant Unknown/ Sensitive Unknown/ Sensitive
Pre-Extensive Drug Resistance (Pre -XDR) Resistant Resistant Resistant Unknown/ Sensitive
Extensive Drug Resistance (XDR) Resistant Resistant Resistant Resistant

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text:
Match the following IT platforms with their relevant application.
IT- Platform: Used for:
1.) Kilkari a.) Leprosy patient monitoring
2.) Mobile academy b.) TB patient monitoring
3.) Nikshay c.) Pregnant women and new mothers
4.) Nikusth d.) Training of ASHA
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a:

IT- Platform: Used for:
1.) Kilkari c.) Pregnant women and new mothers
2.) Mobile academy d.) Training of ASHA
3.) Nikshay b.) TB patient monitoring
4.) Nikusth a.) Leprosy patient monitoring

 

Kilkari is a new scheme under NRHM(National Rural Health Mission). It is a mobile health education service that provides pregnant women, new mothers, and their families with timely, accessible, accurate and relevant information about Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal and Child health. It consists of an Interactive pre-recorded Voice Response (IVR) system, which informs pregnant women about pregnancy and child health care, covering the expected events from the 4th month of conception until the child is one year old. Each call is for 2 minutes and services are available in all states in their regional dialects.

Mobile Academy is a Reproductive Maternal Neonatal and Child health training course designed to refresh ASHA workers’ knowledge of life-saving preventative health behaviours and improve the quality of their engagement with new and expecting mothers and their families. 

Nikusth is a real-time web-based system for data management for leprosy cases. It is software for monitoring leprosy patients, with a patient tracking mechanism launched by the Health & Family Welfare Minister Government of India.

NIKSHAY is a web-based solution for monitoring  TB patients. (The word is a combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB).

questions.text: Auxiliary liver transplantation is beneficial in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Auxiliary liver transplantation is beneficial in acute liver failure.

Auxiliary liver transplantation involves implanting a healthy liver graft heterotopically or orthotopically while leaving the whole or part of the native liver intact. The auxiliary partial orthotopic LT (APOLT) technique is used in patients with acute liver failure and metabolic diseases (primary hypercholesterolemia, glycogen storage disorders, organic acidemia, etc). In acute liver failure, this technique helps in native liver regeneration and immunosuppression withdrawal. In children with metabolic liver diseases, this technique helps in future gene therapy.

Options B, C, and D are chronic liver diseases not suitable for auxiliary liver transplantation.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after penetrating trauma to the chest. His heart sounds are muffled and the ECG findings are given below. Which of the following is not indicated in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
The given patient came with penetrating chest trauma and had muffled heart sounds. The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes). All these features suggest the diagnosis of Cardiac Tamponade secondary to penetrating trauma. Needle Pericardiocentesis is not done for patients with Cardiac tamponade after penetrating trauma.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output. The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade are Beck's triad, which consists of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure.

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

e-Fast is diagnostic of cardiac tamponade as it detects the free fluid in the pericardial sac. Rapid infusion of as little as 250 ml intravenous normal saline improves the cardiac haemodynamics in a significant proportion of tamponade patients. Pericardiocentesis has no role in the management of cardiac tamponade secondary to penetrating myocardial injury. It can be done for blunt trauma leading to tamponade.

The correct immediate treatment of tamponade is operative, either via a subxiphoid window or by open surgery (sternotomy or left anterolateral thoracotomy), with the repair of the heart in emergency or in OT.

questions.text:
As per the IAP standard treatment guidelines 2022, which of the following factors are considered risk factors for developing subsequent epilepsy in a child with febrile seizures?

 

  1. Family history of epilepsy
  2. Any neurodevelopmental problem
  3. Prolonged or focal febrile seizures
  4. Febrile status epilepticus
questions.solution:
Risk factors for developing subsequent epilepsy in a child with febrile seizures include:

  1. Family history of epilepsy
  2. Any neurodevelopmental problem
  3. Prolonged or focal febrile seizures
  4. Febrile status epilepticus

Febrile seizures are described as seizures that occur in children of the age of 6–60 months with a temperature of 38ºC (100.4°F) or higher, without underlying intracranial infections or prior unprovoked seizures. Epilepsy is a disorder of the brain characterized by a predisposition to generate repeated seizures. Children with simple febrile seizures have a 1% risk of developing epilepsy by the age of 7 years (same as the general population) and 2.4% by 25 years of age.

questions.text: Which is the new IAP recommendation for the first line treatment of Rickets in children?

choices.text: Bolus on day 1, followed by Daily Vitamin D supplementation

questions.solution:
The IAP(Indian Academy of Pediatrics) now recommends daily  Vitamin D as the first line of treatment in children with rickets.

A deficiency of vitamin D results in poor mineralization of the bone, leading to rickets in children. Rickets presents with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain once the child starts to walk. Prominent costochondral joints (rachitic rosary), craniotabes, scoliosis, fractures, dental anomalies and alopecia may also be seen. Radiological features show cupping at metaphyses, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

IAP has updated the treatment guidelines for children with rickets:

Daily treatment with oral Vitamin D preparations is recommended, as daily supplementation is more physiological. The duration of treatment is at least 12 weeks. Vitamin D dosage is 2000 I.U in infants and 3000 I.U in children over one year of age. Calcium intake of 50-75 mg/kg/day (not exceeding 500 mg/day) must be ensured through diet or supplementation with vitamin D. Monitoring during treatment is done with radiographs and lab values of Serum calcium, phosphate, alkaline phosphatase and serum 25 (OH)D levels.

Stoss therapy was earlier used for treating Vitamin D deficiency. Here, 300,000-600,000 IU of vitamin D was administered orally or intramuscularly in 2 or 4 doses over 1 day.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not included in NP-NCD?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is not included in the NP-NCD program.

The NPCDCS (National Program for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke) has been changed to NP-NCD (National Program for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases). It now includes initiatives and guidelines on the prevention and management of new diseases like:

  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
  • Chronic Kidney disease
  • Asthma, COPD
  • STEMI
  • Stroke

It continues to include the diseases already covered in NPCDCS. For effective program management, the NCD divisions have been established at National, State, and District headquarters to ensure the activities' planning, implementation, monitoring, and evaluation.

The NPCDCS program was first introduced under the NHM(National Health Mission) umbrella in 2010, to prevent screen, and treat Non-communicable diseases in India. In 2018, Non-Communicable Diseases like Cardiovascular diseases, Cancer, Chronic Respiratory Diseases, Diabetes, and other NCDs were estimated to account for 63% of all deaths, thus making them the leading causes of death. Hypothyroidism has never been a part of the program.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the REDS path in the National suicide prevention strategy?

choices.text: Reduce suicidal deaths by 2% in the next 5 years
Enhance health services to provide suicide prevention strategies
Develop community resilience, and societal support for suicide prevention

questions.solution:
The National Suicide Prevention Strategy (NSPS) is a multisectoral approach that will involve national and international government ministries, families and communities, and educational institutes. It aims to reduce suicide mortality by 10% in India by 2030.

It recommends REDS path for suicide prevention.

  • Reinforce leadership, partnership, and institutional capacity in the country
  • Enhance the health services capacity to provide suicide prevention services
  • Develop community resilience, societal support for suicide prevention and reduce stigma against suicidal behaviours
  • Strengthen surveillance and evidence generation. 

Objectives

  • To establish effective surveillance mechanism for suicide prevention in next 3 years
  • To establish psychiatric OPDs that provide suicide prevention services through District Mental Health Programme, within next 5 years
  • To integrate mental well-being curriculum in all educational institutes within next 8 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Trofinetide is the newly FDA-approved drug for the treatment of Rett syndrome.

The mechanism by which trofinetide exerts therapeutic effects in patients with Rett syndrome is unknown. It is a synthetic analog of the amino‐terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) designed to treat the core symptoms of Rett syndrome by potentially reducing neuroinflammation and supporting synaptic function of the protein fragment glypromate (GPE). IGF-1 is produced by both major types of brain cells – neurons and glia; IGF-1 in the brain is critical for both normal development and response to injury and disease. Trofinetide has been shown to inhibit the production of inflammatory cytokines, inhibit overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and increase the amount of available IGF-1 that can bind to IGF-1 receptors.

It is Indicated for the treatment of Rett syndrome.

Adverse effects include diarrhea, vomiting, fever, seizure, anxiety, decreased appetite, fatigue, nasopharyngitis

 

Other options:

Option A: Olcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist which was considered for the treatment of migraine, but discontinued.

Option B: Lasmiditan is a nontriptan 5HT1F receptor–selective agonist and is used to treat migraine.

Option D: Erenumab is a CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) blocking antibody used in the treatment migraine. 

 

Note: The spelling of the drug in the options has been corrected from Trofinitide to Trofinetide.

questions.text: Open vial policy is not applicable to which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
Open vial policy is not applicable for BCG and measles vaccines.

It is applicable for:

  • DPT
  • TT
  • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • OPV
  • Pentavalent vaccine
  • Rotavirus vaccine (New version with the VVM on the side)

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child with a cough and cold for the last 7 days is taken to an ASHA worker by his mother. On examination, the child had a respiratory rate of 42 breaths/min and no chest indrawing or grunting.  What would be the next step followed by the ASHA worker?

choices.text: ASHA herself advices for home-based care
ASHA  refers the child to the nearby PHC
ASHA gives the first dose of oral Amoxicillin
ASHA gives the first dose of injectable Amoxicillin and refers to District hospital

questions.solution:
The next best step for the ASHA worker is to herself give advice for home-based care.

The 6-month-old child with a cough and cold for 7 days, having a respiratory rate of 42 breaths per minute and no chest indrawings or grunting is classified as "No pneumonia". According to the latest SAANS guidelines (Social Awareness and Actions to Neutralize Pneumonia Successfully), for a child with No Pneumonia, an ASHA worker on her own will advise Home-based care for the child. 

Home-based care includes:

  • Exclusive breastfeeding for <6 months old child as much as possible.
  • For older children give plenty of oral fluids
  • Home-made soothing cough remedies can be given to children more than 6 months old.
  • Mothers should be taught about the danger signs and report to the ASHA worker or ANM if any danger signs develop.

For classifying Pneumonia, SAANS guidelines of India are similar to the IMNCI protocols of WHO, except it allows ASHA to take the decision for advising Home based treatment as she has been trained for classifying Pneumonia. Also in the SAANS guidelines Chest indrawing is a feature of severe pneumonia, while it comes under Pneumonia in the IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: All of the following surgical procedures can be conducted in a Primary Health Center (PHC) except _____.
questions.solution:
Cholecystectomy is not a surgical procedure that is conducted in a PHC. The surgical procedures done in PHC include suturing of wounds, incision and drainage of abscesses, vasectomy, tubectomy, and hydrocelectomy.

Services provided under PHC:

  1. General services: OPD, teleconsultation services
  2. Emergency services
  3. 24x7 labor rooms
  4. Antenatal clinics, non-communicable diseases (NCD) clinics
  5. Rotational specialist clinics
  6. Surgical procedures:
    • Suturing of wounds
    • Incision and drainage of abscesses
    • Vasectomy, tubectomy, hydrocelectomy in PHCs with a functional minor OT, and standard infection-prevention protocols
  7. Antenatal care and services:
    • Detecting pregnancy 
    • Provision of ANC and counseling services
    • Identification, management, and referral of high-risk pregnancies
    • Detection of alarming signs during pregnancy and labor with timely and appropriate referral
    • Monitoring high-risk pregnancies
    • Management of malaria for pregnant women, as per National Center for Vector Borne Diseases Control (NCVBDC) guidelines
    • Management of tuberculosis during pregnancy
    • Management of mild/moderate anemia
    • Management of gestational diabetes mellitus, as per Government of India guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about the Indian Hypertension Control Initiative (IHCI)?

choices.text: The IHCI monitoring personnel includes cardiovascular health officers and senior treatment supervisors
Provision of real-time blood pressure monitoring for all patients via information systems
The IHCI provides 30-day medication for individuals registered for hypertension management
The target is a 90% reduction in the prevalence of hypertension by the year 2025

questions.solution:
The false statement about the Indian Hypertension Control Initiative is a 90% reduction in the prevalence of hypertension by the year 2025. 

The IHCI is an initiative by the MoHFW, WHO, ICMR, and state governments to control hypertension in India. It has adopted the goal of “25 by 25” to reduce the prevalence of hypertension in India by 25% by 2025. The activities of IHCI are monitored by the cardiovascular health officers (CVHO's) at the state and district level and by the senior treatment supervisors (STS's) at the sub-district level. The IHCI has strengthened the prevention of hypertension by ensuring the provision of antihypertensive medications for 30 days to all patients registered under the IHCI.

The 5 components of IHCI are:

  1. Use of standardized hypertension treatment protocols approved by national and global policies.
  2. Availability of recommended protocol drugs to provide a regular and uninterrupted supply of medications.
  3. Task-sharing and team-based care involving nurses, health workers, and ASHAs to improve treatment compliance.
  4. Patient-centered services provide easy access to BP monitoring at Health & wellness centers and PHCs.
  5. Information systems that provide real-time BP monitoring to improve patient follow-ups: Use of the “Simple App” in all IHCI states.

*Note: Amlodipine, telmisartan, and chlorthalidone are the drugs of choice in the standardized treatment protocols of the IHCI.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male was diagnosed with a colorectal polyp. He was operated and a sessile, hyperplastic polyp measuring 24mm in diameter was completely removed. No evidence of an invasive disease was noted. What follow-up should be advised to this patient?

choices.text: Site check after 6 months by colonoscopy

questions.solution:
For a sessile, hyperplastic colorectal polyp measuring 24mm in diameter, follow-up is done with a one-off colonoscopy at 3 years.

Colorectal polyp is the term used for any protrusion of the mucosa of the colon and rectum. It encompasses a variety of histologically different tumours (like inflammatory polyps, hamartomatous polyps, serrated polyps, adenomas and malignant polyps). Polyps can occur singly, synchronously in small numbers or as part of a polyposis syndrome. 

Metaplastic or hyperplastic polyps are common and are generally considered benign. Sessile serrated lesions and hyperplastic polyps ≥10 mm may lead to dysplasia and malignancy along what is termed as the ‘serrated pathway’. Such polyps should be removed and a follow-up colonoscopy should be arranged.

Based on the histological findings upon excision, follow-up is done as below:

Biopsy findings   Follow-up protocol
Colo rectal cancer   A colonoscopy is done every year
>20mm sessile polyp- -if completely resected One-off Followup Colonoscopy after 3 years
  -if residual disease present Site check at 2-6 months, yearly colonoscopy thereafter
High-risk polyp and    One-off Follow-up Colonoscopy after 3 years
Low-risk polyp   No specific follow-up

Thus in this patient follow-up colonoscopy after three years should be advised to look for recurrence.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding liver transplantation (LT)?

choices.text: The ideal graft weight to recipient weight ratio (GRWR) in living donor transplant is >0.8 %.
In domino LT, liver grafts with metabolic diseases is used as they are structurally and functionally normal.
Extended criteria donors and paired-exchange LT decrease waitlist mortality.
Reduced size LT involves dividing the whole liver into right lobe for an adult patient and left lateral segments for pediatric patients.

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding liver transplantation is option D. Reduced-size liver transplantation involves the resection of a full-size liver to appropriately fit in the abdominal cavity of small adults/adolescents. It is reserved only for urgent transplantation. On the contrary, split LT involves dividing the whole donor liver into a left lateral segment (segments II and III) for a pediatric patient and a right lobe (segments I, IV-VIII) for an adult patient.

Option A: The required graft volume in a living donor transplant is measured by graft weight to recipient weight ratio (GRWR) or ratio of graft volume (GV) to recipient standard liver volume (SLV). The ideal GRWR is >0.8 % or GV/SLV is > 35%. The remnant donor liver mass is kept at >30% for safe regeneration.

Option B: Domino liver transplant involves transplanting a liver from a donor with metabolic disease (eg: familial amyloid polyneuropathy) to a recipient with end-stage liver disease (eg: hepatocellular carcinoma). The donor also receives an LT (healthy donor) and is prioritized over the end-stage liver disease recipient. As a liver with metabolic diseases is structurally and functionally normal, it can prolong the recipient’s life by at least 15-20 years as they will not develop the metabolic disease immediately.

Option C: Extended criteria donors/ECDs (liver grafts extracted from donors after circulatory death) and paired-exchange technique are used to decrease waitlist mortality. However, ECDs have poor graft function due to prolonged hypoxia and are associated with higher infection transmission and biliary complications.
